concepts.title: Interest Rate Components
concepts.desc: Nominal rate = Real risk-free rate + Inflation premium + Default risk premium + Liquidity premium + Maturity premium.

concepts.title: Holding Period Return (HPR)
concepts.desc: Total return earned from holding an asset over a single period, including price change and income.

concepts.title: Arithmetic vs Geometric Mean
concepts.desc: Arithmetic mean is the simple average of returns; geometric mean accounts for compounding. Geometric ≤ Arithmetic always.

concepts.title: Harmonic Mean
concepts.desc: Used for averaging ratios like P/E or dollar-cost averaging. Always ≤ Geometric mean ≤ Arithmetic mean.

concepts.title: Money-Weighted Return (MWR)
concepts.desc: IRR of all cash flows; sensitive to timing and size of external cash flows. Reflects investor experience.

concepts.title: Time-Weighted Return (TWR)
concepts.desc: Geometric mean of sub-period returns; not affected by external cash flows. Reflects manager performance.

concepts.title: Continuously Compounded Return
concepts.desc: r<sub>cc</sub> = ln(1 + HPR). Allows additive compounding across time periods.

concepts.title: Gross vs Net Return
concepts.desc: Gross = before management fees; Net = after all fees. Pre-tax vs after-tax returns also critical.

formulas.name: Holding Period Return
formulas.where: P<sub>0</sub> = beginning price, P<sub>1</sub> = ending price, D<sub>1</sub> = income/dividend

formulas.name: Geometric Mean Return
formulas.where: R<sub>i</sub> = return in period i, n = number of periods

formulas.name: Harmonic Mean
formulas.where: n = number of observations, X<sub>i</sub> = individual values

formulas.name: Annualized Return
formulas.where: c = number of periods per year

decisions.question: Which mean return to use?
use: Arithmetic mean: for forward-looking expected single-period returns
Geometric mean: for historical multi-period compound performance
Harmonic mean: for dollar-cost averaging or averaging P/E ratios
avoid: Arithmetic mean when evaluating past compounded growth
Geometric mean for expected future single-period estimates

decisions.question: Money-weighted vs Time-weighted return?
use: MWR when evaluating the investor's actual experience
TWR when evaluating the portfolio manager's skill
avoid: MWR for manager comparison (distorted by client cash flows)
TWR when investor controls timing of cash flows

pitfalls: Confusing arithmetic mean (always higher) with geometric mean for historical performance
Using MWR to evaluate manager performance — it reflects investor timing, not skill
Forgetting that continuously compounded returns are additive over time but HPRs are not
Not annualizing returns correctly: must compound, not simply multiply by periods per year
Ignoring the impact of leverage on returns — leveraged return = R<sub>portfolio</sub> + (V<sub>B</sub>/V<sub>E</sub>)(R<sub>p</sub> - r<sub>D</sub>)

examples.title: Geometric vs Arithmetic Mean
examples.problem: An investment returns +20% in Year 1 and -10% in Year 2. Calculate both means.
examples.solution: Arithmetic = (20% + (-10%))/2 = 5%. Geometric = [(1.20)(0.90)]<sup>1/2</sup> - 1 = (1.08)<sup>0.5</sup> - 1 = 3.92%. The geometric mean better reflects actual compounded growth.

questions.explanation: Geometric = [(1.30)(0.80)]^(1/2) - 1 = (1.04)^(0.5) - 1 = 1.0198 - 1 = 1.98%. Actually: (1.30)(0.80) = 1.04, sqrt(1.04) = 1.0198, so 1.98%. Wait let me recalculate: sqrt(1.04) = 1.01980, so 1.98% is answer B. Let me fix: correct answer is index 1.

questions.question: Which return measure is most appropriate for evaluating a portfolio manager's performance?
questions.explanation: TWR removes the effect of external cash flows (which the manager doesn't control), making it the appropriate measure for manager evaluation.

questions.question: The harmonic mean is most appropriate when calculating the average:
options: Cost per share with dollar-cost averaging
questions.explanation: The harmonic mean gives the correct average cost per share when equal dollar amounts are invested at different prices (dollar-cost averaging).

The geometric mean return is always less than or equal to the arithmetic mean return.
questions.explanation: This is always true. They are equal only when all returns are identical. The greater the variability, the larger the difference.

questions.question: An investor earns a nominal return of 8% when inflation is 3%. The approximate real return is:
questions.explanation: Exact: (1.08)/(1.03) - 1 = 4.85%. The approximation (8% - 3% = 5%) overstates the real return slightly.

modules.title: Time Value of Money in Finance

concepts.title: Present Value (PV)
concepts.desc: The current worth of a future cash flow discounted at the appropriate rate. Foundation of all valuation.

concepts.title: Future Value (FV)
concepts.desc: The value of a current amount after earning interest over a specified period.

concepts.title: Annuity
concepts.desc: A series of equal cash flows at regular intervals. Ordinary annuity: payments at END. Annuity due: payments at BEGINNING.

concepts.title: Perpetuity
concepts.desc: An annuity that pays forever. PV = PMT/r. Growing perpetuity: PV = PMT/(r - g).

concepts.title: Cash Flow Additivity
concepts.desc: PV of a series of cash flows equals the sum of the PVs of individual cash flows. Basis for no-arbitrage pricing.

concepts.title: Implied Return
concepts.desc: The discount rate that equates the PV of future cash flows to the current market price. For bonds: YTM; for stocks: implied return from DDM.

concepts.title: Implied Forward Rate
concepts.desc: Future interest rate implied by current spot rates via no-arbitrage. (1+S<sub>2</sub>)² = (1+S<sub>1</sub>)(1+f<sub>1,1</sub>).

formulas.name: Future Value

formulas.name: PV of Perpetuity
formulas.where: PMT = periodic payment, r = discount rate

formulas.name: Implied Forward Rate
formulas.where: S = spot rate, f = forward rate

decisions.question: Ordinary Annuity vs Annuity Due?
use: Ordinary annuity: most bonds (coupons at end of period), most loans
Annuity due: lease payments at start, insurance premiums
avoid: Using ordinary annuity formula when payments occur at beginning of period

decisions.question: When to use Cash Flow Additivity?
use: Pricing bonds by discounting each coupon separately at spot rates
No-arbitrage pricing of derivatives
Implied forward rate calculations
avoid: When cash flows are not independent or when there are embedded options

pitfalls: Forgetting to adjust for annuity due: PV<sub>due</sub> = PV<sub>ordinary</sub> × (1 + r)
Using wrong compounding frequency — always match rate to period
Confusing stated annual rate with EAR when compounding is non-annual
Not recognizing that perpetuity formula assumes first payment is one period away

concepts.title: Measures of Central Tendency
concepts.desc: Mean (arithmetic, geometric, harmonic), median (middle value, robust to outliers), mode (most frequent).

concepts.title: Quantiles
concepts.desc: Quartiles divide data into 4 parts, quintiles into 5, deciles into 10, percentiles into 100.

concepts.title: Variance & Standard Deviation
concepts.desc: Variance = average squared deviation from mean. SD = √Variance. Population uses N; sample uses N-1.

concepts.title: Coefficient of Variation (CV)
concepts.desc: CV = s/X̄. Measures relative dispersion — useful for comparing risk across assets with different means.

concepts.title: Skewness
concepts.desc: Positive skew: right tail longer (mean > median > mode). Negative skew: left tail longer (mean < median < mode).

concepts.title: Kurtosis
concepts.desc: Leptokurtic (excess kurtosis > 0): fatter tails, more peaked. Platykurtic (< 0): thinner tails. Mesokurtic = normal.

concepts.title: Correlation
concepts.desc: Standardized covariance: ρ = Cov(X,Y) / (σ<sub>X</sub>σ<sub>Y</sub>). Range: -1 to +1. Measures linear association only.

formulas.name: Population Variance
formulas.where: μ = population mean, N = population size

formulas.name: Sample Variance
formulas.where: X̄ = sample mean, n-1 for Bessel correction

decisions.question: When to use Median vs Mean?
use: Median: when data is skewed or has outliers
Mean: when data is symmetric and approximately normal
avoid: Mean for highly skewed distributions like income or housing prices

decisions.question: When to worry about kurtosis?
use: Risk management: leptokurtic returns mean more extreme events than normal distribution predicts
VaR calculations: fat tails underestimate tail risk if assuming normality
avoid: Ignoring excess kurtosis when assessing portfolio risk

pitfalls: Using N instead of N-1 for sample variance (undercounts variability)
Assuming correlation implies causation
Forgetting that correlation only measures LINEAR relationships
For negatively skewed returns: mean < median < mode (exam favorite)
Excess kurtosis = Kurtosis - 3 (normal distribution has kurtosis of 3)

examples.title: CV Comparison
examples.problem: Fund A: mean return 8%, SD 12%. Fund B: mean return 14%, SD 20%. Which has more risk per unit of return?
examples.solution: CV<sub>A</sub> = 12/8 = 1.50. CV<sub>B</sub> = 20/14 = 1.43. Fund A has MORE risk per unit of return (higher CV).

questions.question: For a negatively skewed distribution, the order from smallest to largest is:
questions.explanation: Negative skew: mean < median < mode. The left tail pulls the mean down.

questions.question: A distribution with excess kurtosis greater than zero is called:
questions.explanation: Leptokurtic distributions have fatter tails and more peaked center than normal (excess kurtosis > 0).

questions.question: Given Cov(A,B) = 0.006, σ<sub>A</sub> = 0.10, σ<sub>B</sub> = 0.15, the correlation is:
The coefficient of variation is most useful for:
options: Comparing the relative dispersion of datasets with different means
Measuring the symmetry of a distribution
questions.explanation: CV = s/mean, allowing comparison of risk relative to return across different investments.

questions.question: Sample variance uses (n-1) in the denominator because:
options: It corrects for bias in estimating population variance
questions.explanation: Bessel's correction (n-1) provides an unbiased estimator of the population variance. Using n would systematically underestimate it.

concepts.title: Expected Value
concepts.desc: E(X) = Σ P(x<sub>i</sub>) × x<sub>i</sub>. The probability-weighted average of all possible outcomes.

concepts.title: Conditional Probability
concepts.desc: P(A|B) = P(AB) / P(B). The probability of A given that B has occurred.

concepts.title: Total Probability Rule
concepts.desc: P(A) = P(A|B)P(B) + P(A|B<sup>c</sup>)P(B<sup>c</sup>). Weights conditional probabilities by scenario probabilities.

concepts.title: Bayes' Formula
concepts.desc: Updates prior probabilities with new information: P(B|A) = P(A|B) × P(B) / P(A). Crucial for updating investment views.

concepts.title: Probability Trees
concepts.desc: Visual tool showing sequential conditional probabilities. Multiply along branches, add across endpoints.

concepts.title: Variance via Expectations
concepts.desc: Var(X) = E(X²) - [E(X)]² = Σ P(x<sub>i</sub>)(x<sub>i</sub> - E(X))²

formulas.name: Multiplication Rule
formulas.where: Joint probability of A and B

decisions.question: When to use Bayes' Formula?
use: Updating probability estimates with new evidence
Medical/diagnostic testing problems
Revising economic forecasts with new data

pitfalls: Confusing P(A|B) with P(B|A) — they are NOT the same
Not exhaustively listing all scenarios in total probability calculations
Forgetting to normalize in Bayes' formula (denominator = total probability of evidence)

examples.title: Bayes' Update
examples.problem: Prior P(recession) = 30%. A leading indicator is negative: P(negative|recession) = 80%, P(negative|no recession) = 20%. Update recession probability.

questions.question: Bayes' formula is used to:
options: Update prior probabilities with new information
questions.explanation: Bayes' formula allows updating prior probability estimates when new information becomes available.

questions.question: The total probability rule is most useful for:
options: Computing expected values across mutually exclusive scenarios
Testing if two events are independent
Measuring the mode of a distribution
questions.explanation: The total probability rule weights conditional probabilities by scenario probabilities to get unconditional expected values.

questions.question: P(A) = 0.6, P(B|A) = 0.3. What is P(AB)?

concepts.title: Portfolio Expected Return
concepts.desc: E(R<sub>p</sub>) = Σ w<sub>i</sub> E(R<sub>i</sub>). Weighted average of individual expected returns.

concepts.title: Portfolio Variance (2 assets)
concepts.desc: σ²<sub>p</sub> = w²<sub>1</sub>σ²<sub>1</sub> + w²<sub>2</sub>σ²<sub>2</sub> + 2w<sub>1</sub>w<sub>2</sub>Cov(1,2). Key: correlation drives diversification benefit.

concepts.title: Diversification Effect
concepts.desc: Unless ρ = +1, portfolio SD < weighted average of individual SDs. Lower correlation = more diversification benefit.

concepts.title: Normal Distribution Properties
concepts.desc: 68% within ±1σ, 95% within ±1.96σ, 99% within ±2.58σ. Skewness = 0, kurtosis = 3.

concepts.title: Safety-First Ratio (SFRatio)
concepts.desc: SFRatio = [E(R<sub>p</sub>) - R<sub>threshold</sub>] / σ<sub>p</sub>. Choose portfolio with highest SFRatio (fewest SDs above disaster level).

formulas.name: Portfolio Variance (2 assets)
formulas.where: w = weights, ρ = correlation, σ = standard deviation

formulas.name: Z-score
formulas.where: Converts value to standard normal units

decisions.question: Effect of correlation on portfolio risk?
use: ρ = +1: no diversification, portfolio SD = weighted average
ρ = 0: significant diversification
ρ = -1: maximum diversification, can create zero-variance portfolio
avoid: Assuming diversification eliminates all risk — systematic risk remains

pitfalls: Portfolio variance has a cross-term (2w<sub>1</sub>w<sub>2</sub>Cov) — don't forget it
With n assets, there are n(n-1)/2 unique covariances needed
Safety-First criterion: choose the HIGHEST SFRatio (not lowest)
Normal distribution: 95% confidence uses 1.96, NOT 2.00

leaves: ρ < 1: portfolio SD < weighted avg SD

questions.question: If two assets have a correlation of +1.0, the portfolio standard deviation is:
options: Less than the weighted average of individual standard deviations
Equal to the weighted average of individual standard deviations
questions.explanation: With perfect positive correlation (ρ=+1), there is no diversification benefit. Portfolio SD equals the weighted average of individual SDs.

questions.question: E(R<sub>p</sub>)=12%, σ<sub>p</sub>=18%, threshold return=3%. Safety-First Ratio is:
As more assets are added to a portfolio, the portfolio variance:
options: Approaches the average covariance of the assets
questions.explanation: With many assets, individual variances become negligible, and portfolio variance approaches the average covariance. This is why systematic risk (covariance) cannot be diversified away.

questions.question: Approximately what percentage of observations lie within ±1.96 standard deviations of the mean in a normal distribution?
questions.explanation: 95% of observations fall within ±1.96 standard deviations of the mean in a normal distribution.

concepts.title: Lognormal Distribution
concepts.desc: If ln(X) is normally distributed, X follows a lognormal distribution. Bounded below by 0 — natural for asset prices.

concepts.title: Continuous Compounding
concepts.desc: If r<sub>cc</sub> is normally distributed, then the price relative (1+R) is lognormally distributed.

concepts.title: Monte Carlo Simulation
concepts.desc: Uses random number generation to simulate thousands of scenarios. Useful when analytical solutions are impossible.

concepts.title: Bootstrapping
concepts.desc: Resampling with replacement from historical data. Does not assume any particular distribution.

formulas.name: Lognormal Price
formulas.where: r<sub>cc</sub> = continuously compounded return, T = time

decisions.question: When to use Monte Carlo vs Bootstrapping?
use: Monte Carlo: when you have a model/distribution to simulate from
Bootstrapping: when you want to let historical data speak without distributional assumptions
avoid: Monte Carlo when the underlying model is misspecified
Bootstrapping with very small sample sizes

pitfalls: Monte Carlo results depend on the assumptions of the model — garbage in, garbage out
Lognormal returns cannot be negative (prices > 0), but normal returns CAN be negative
Bootstrapping assumes the historical sample is representative of the population

examples.title: Continuous Compounding
examples.problem: A stock is priced at $50. If the continuously compounded return over 1 year is 8%, what is the ending price?

questions.question: The lognormal distribution is most appropriate for modeling:
questions.explanation: Asset prices cannot be negative, which matches the lognormal distribution (bounded below by 0). Returns can be negative, so they are better modeled as normal.

questions.question: A key limitation of Monte Carlo simulation is:
options: Its results depend on the quality of input assumptions
It can only handle one asset at a time
questions.explanation: Monte Carlo is garbage in, garbage out. The quality of results depends entirely on the assumptions about distributions, correlations, and processes.

questions.question: Bootstrapping differs from Monte Carlo simulation in that bootstrapping:
options: Resamples from historical data with replacement
questions.explanation: Bootstrapping resamples from actual historical observations with replacement, making no assumptions about the underlying distribution.

concepts.title: Simple Random Sampling
concepts.desc: Every member of the population has an equal probability of being selected. Foundation of statistical inference.

concepts.title: Stratified Random Sampling
concepts.desc: Divide population into subgroups (strata), then sample from each. Ensures representation of all groups.

concepts.title: Central Limit Theorem (CLT)
concepts.desc: For n ≥ 30, the sampling distribution of the sample mean is approximately normal, regardless of the population distribution.

concepts.title: Standard Error
concepts.desc: SE = σ / √n. Measures the precision of the sample mean as an estimator. Decreases with larger samples.

concepts.title: Confidence Interval
concepts.desc: Point estimate ± (Critical value × Standard Error). 95% CI uses z = 1.96 for large samples.

formulas.name: Standard Error of Mean
formulas.formula: SE = σ / √n (or s / √n if σ unknown)
formulas.where: σ = population SD, n = sample size

formulas.name: Confidence Interval
formulas.where: z<sub>α/2</sub> = critical value for confidence level

formulas.name: Confidence Interval (t)
formulas.where: Used when σ unknown and n < 30; df = n-1

decisions.question: z-statistic vs t-statistic?
use: z: population σ known, or n ≥ 30
t: population σ unknown AND n < 30
avoid: Using z when sample is small and σ is unknown — use t-distribution

pitfalls: CLT requires n ≥ 30 for non-normal populations; smaller n okay if population is normal
Standard error decreases with √n, NOT n — quadrupling sample size only halves SE
Wider confidence interval does NOT mean more precise — it means LESS precise

examples.title: 95% Confidence Interval
examples.problem: Sample mean = 10%, s = 5%, n = 36. Construct a 95% CI.

leaves: z for known σ or large n
t for unknown σ and small n

questions.question: The Central Limit Theorem states that for large samples, the sampling distribution of the sample mean is approximately:
questions.explanation: The CLT guarantees that the distribution of sample means approaches normality as n increases, regardless of the population distribution.

questions.question: If σ = 20 and n = 100, the standard error of the sample mean is:
A t-distribution is most appropriate when:
options: The population is normal and σ is known
The population is non-normal and n is large
The population variance is unknown and n is small
questions.explanation: Use t-distribution when population variance is unknown and the sample size is small (n < 30).

concepts.title: Null & Alternative Hypotheses
concepts.desc: H<sub>0</sub>: status quo (what we try to reject). H<sub>a</sub>: what we want to prove. We never "accept" H<sub>0</sub>, only fail to reject.

concepts.title: Type I and Type II Errors
concepts.desc: Type I (α): reject true H<sub>0</sub> (false positive). Type II (β): fail to reject false H<sub>0</sub> (false negative). Power = 1 - β.

concepts.title: Test Statistic
concepts.desc: test stat = (sample stat - hypothesized value) / standard error. Compare to critical value.

concepts.title: p-value
concepts.desc: Smallest significance level at which H<sub>0</sub> would be rejected. Reject H<sub>0</sub> if p-value < α.

concepts.title: One-tailed vs Two-tailed
concepts.desc: Two-tailed: H<sub>a</sub>: μ ≠ value. One-tailed: H<sub>a</sub>: μ > value or μ < value. Two-tailed has critical values on both sides.

formulas.name: F-test for Variance Equality
formulas.formula: F = s²<sub>1</sub> / s²<sub>2</sub> (larger variance in numerator)

decisions.question: Which test to use?
use: t-test: testing means (unknown σ)
F-test: testing equality of two variances
Chi-square: testing a single variance, contingency tables
avoid: Using z-test when σ is unknown and sample is small

pitfalls: Never say "accept H<sub>0</sub>" — only "fail to reject H<sub>0</sub>"
Type I error rate = significance level (α)
Statistical significance ≠ economic significance — large samples can find trivial differences
Data mining/snooping bias: finding patterns in data by running many tests

examples.title: Hypothesis Test
examples.problem: Test if mean return differs from 5% at 5% significance. Sample: X̄=7%, s=8%, n=64.
examples.solution: t = (7%-5%)/(8%/√64) = 2%/1% = 2.00. Critical value at 5% two-tailed ≈ 1.96. Since |2.00| > 1.96, reject H<sub>0</sub>.

branches.label: Errors
leaves: Type II: fail to reject false H<sub>0</sub> (β)

questions.question: A Type I error occurs when a researcher:
options: Fails to reject a false null hypothesis
questions.explanation: Type I error is rejecting H<sub>0</sub> when it is actually true (false positive). The probability equals the significance level α.

questions.question: If the p-value of a test is 0.03 and the significance level is 0.05:
questions.explanation: Since p-value (0.03) < α (0.05), we reject the null hypothesis.

questions.question: Which test is used to compare the variances of two populations?
questions.explanation: The F-test compares two variances using the ratio s²<sub>1</sub>/s²<sub>2</sub>.

questions.question: Increasing the sample size will most likely:
options: Increase the power of the test
questions.explanation: Larger samples reduce standard error, making it easier to detect true effects, thus increasing power (1-β).

modules.title: Parametric and Non-Parametric Tests of Independence

concepts.title: Parametric Correlation Test
concepts.desc: Tests whether population correlation ρ = 0. t = r√(n-2) / √(1-r²) with df = n-2.

concepts.title: Spearman Rank Correlation
concepts.desc: Non-parametric alternative. Ranks data, then calculates correlation of ranks. Robust to outliers and non-linearity.

concepts.title: Contingency Table Tests
concepts.desc: Chi-square test of independence using observed vs expected frequencies. χ² = Σ(O-E)²/E.

formulas.name: Chi-Square Statistic
formulas.where: O = observed frequency, E = expected frequency

formulas.name: Expected Frequency
formulas.formula: E<sub>ij</sub> = (Row total × Column total) / Grand total

decisions.question: Parametric vs Non-parametric correlation?
use: Parametric: when data is approximately normal
Spearman: when data is ordinal, has outliers, or non-linear relationship
avoid: Parametric test on heavily skewed or ordinal data

pitfalls: Correlation = 0 does NOT mean no relationship — could be non-linear
Spearman rank correlation detects monotonic (not just linear) relationships
Chi-square test requires expected frequencies ≥ 5 in each cell

questions.question: Spearman rank correlation is preferred over Pearson correlation when:
options: The sample size is very large
The data is ordinal or contains outliers
questions.explanation: Spearman uses ranks rather than actual values, making it robust to outliers and appropriate for ordinal data or non-linear monotonic relationships.

questions.question: In a chi-square test of independence, the degrees of freedom for an r × c contingency table are:
questions.explanation: df = (rows - 1)(columns - 1) for a contingency table chi-square test.

questions.question: A sample correlation of 0 between two variables means:
options: There is no relationship of any kind
questions.explanation: Zero correlation means no LINEAR relationship. A strong non-linear relationship (e.g., quadratic) can have zero correlation.

concepts.title: Regression Equation
concepts.desc: Ŷ = b<sub>0</sub> + b<sub>1</sub>X. b<sub>0</sub> = intercept, b<sub>1</sub> = slope (change in Y per unit change in X).

concepts.title: R-squared
concepts.desc: Coefficient of determination = proportion of Y's variation explained by X. R² = correlation². Range: 0 to 1.

concepts.title: Standard Error of Estimate (SEE)
concepts.desc: Measures the average distance of actual Y values from the regression line. Lower SEE = better fit.

concepts.title: ANOVA
concepts.desc: SST = SSR + SSE. Total variation = Explained + Unexplained. F = MSR/MSE tests overall significance.

concepts.title: Assumptions
concepts.desc: Linearity, homoscedasticity (constant variance), independence of errors, normality of errors.

decisions.question: How to assess regression quality?
use: R² for goodness of fit
SEE for prediction accuracy
t-test on b<sub>1</sub> for statistical significance
F-test for overall model significance
avoid: Relying solely on R² — high R² doesn't guarantee a good model

pitfalls: In simple regression, t² for the slope = F-statistic (they test the same thing)
R² = r² in simple regression (square of correlation coefficient)
Heteroscedasticity invalidates standard errors — look at residual plots
Correlation/regression does NOT prove causation

questions.question: In simple linear regression, R² equals:
options: The square of the correlation coefficient
The standard error of the estimate
questions.explanation: In simple regression, R² = r² (the square of the Pearson correlation between X and Y).

questions.question: If SST = 400 and SSE = 100, then R² is:
questions.explanation: R² = 1 - SSE/SST = 1 - 100/400 = 1 - 0.25 = 0.75. The model explains 75% of the variation in Y.

questions.question: The standard error of the estimate (SEE) measures:
options: The precision of the slope coefficient
The average prediction error of the regression
The total variation in the dependent variable
The correlation between X and Y
questions.explanation: SEE measures the standard deviation of the residuals — the typical distance between actual and predicted Y values.

concepts.title: Big Data Characteristics
concepts.desc: Volume (large amount), Velocity (speed of generation), Variety (structured/unstructured), Veracity (reliability).

concepts.title: Machine Learning Types
concepts.desc: Supervised: labeled data (classification, regression). Unsupervised: no labels (clustering, dimensionality reduction). Reinforcement: reward-based learning.

concepts.title: Overfitting
concepts.desc: Model fits training data too closely, captures noise, performs poorly on new data. Regularization and cross-validation help prevent it.

concepts.title: Text Analytics / NLP
concepts.desc: Sentiment analysis, topic modeling, and text classification applied to financial documents, news, and social media.

concepts.title: Fintech Applications
concepts.desc: Robo-advisors, algorithmic trading, blockchain, RegTech. Data-driven investment and risk management.

decisions.question: Supervised vs Unsupervised Learning?
use: Supervised: when you have labeled outcomes (predict stock up/down)
Unsupervised: when discovering hidden patterns (cluster similar stocks)
avoid: Supervised learning with insufficient labeled data
Unsupervised when you have clear labels and prediction goals

pitfalls: Overfitting: complex models perform well on training data but poorly out-of-sample
Big data ≠ good data — veracity (quality) matters as much as volume
AI models may have biases embedded in training data
Confusing correlation patterns found by ML with true causal relationships

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the "4 Vs" of big data?
questions.explanation: The 4 Vs are Volume, Velocity, Variety, and Veracity. "Value" is sometimes added as a 5th V but is not part of the standard 4.

questions.question: Overfitting in machine learning refers to:
options: A model that is too simple to capture patterns
A model that captures noise in training data and performs poorly on new data
questions.explanation: Overfitting means the model is too complex, fits noise in the training data, and fails to generalize to new observations.

questions.question: Clustering stocks into groups based on financial characteristics without pre-defined labels is an example of:
questions.explanation: Clustering without labels is unsupervised learning — the algorithm discovers natural groupings in the data.
